title: With biometrics, 5G, and our governments rolling out digital ID programs for licensing, etc., are we moving into an era where our privacy no longer exists? Where are we tracked all the time? - Quora

response.answer_text: No and yes. The privacy laws are still there and some are getting stronger so no, privacy is not going away. However, you can always share your private information voluntarily (in which case it is no longer private). Many people are already doing this, some realize this and are okay with it but there are a ton that don’t even realize what they are giving away so for some people, yes it may not exist. Then there are the benefits to the whole community if privacy were eliminated for certain things. We could never mount an automated COVID-19 tracking system like what Taiwan did without violating several laws (privacy being just one of them), however if you look at the number of deaths per 100,000 people in Taiwan and compare it to the US, you can clearly see the benefit of that kind of invasive tracking system. Taiwan’s cell phone data with location history was tied into the medical records for everyone on that island. Anyone with a COVID-19 diagnosis was back tracked to everyone they came in contact with and those people forward traced and all got messages to quarantine themselves. Learning from Taiwan about fighting Covid-19 — and using EHRs - STAT
